Graphical abstract Nano-sized Wadsley-Roth FeNb11O29, synthesized via Fe-driven phase transformation of Nb2O5, demonstrates superior electronic conductivity, fast kinetics, and exceptional cycling stability, enabled by its narrow bandgap, making it a high-performance anode for advanced fast-charging batteries. Niobium-based oxides show great potential in anode materials for fast-charging lithium-ion batteries, but their practical application remains hindered by intrinsically low conductivity. In this study, we successfully synthesize nano-sized Wadsley-Roth FeNb11O29 through Fe-driven phase transformation of Nb2O5, which delivers a high specific capacity (280.5 mA h g−1 at 0.25 C) along with abundant redox-active sites. Moreover, the Wadsley-Roth shear structure of FeNb11O29 facilitates rapid Li+ diffusion and guarantees exceptional structural stability. Theoretical calculations further confirm that FeNb11O29 has a narrow bandgap, which significantly enhances the conductivity. Owing to these merits, FeNb11O29 achieves a full charge/discharge cycle within merely 25 s at 75 C rate and retains remarkable cycling stability over 2500 cycles. As a consequence, our assembled FeNb11O29||LiFePO4 full cell demonstrates ultra-long cyclability (>10000 cycles) and outstanding fast-charging capability (complete cycling within 2 min at 30 C). These findings highlight nano-sized FeNb11O29 as a highly promising anode candidate for next-generation fast-charging LIBs. Keywords Fast-charging Nano-sized Wadsley-Roth structure Lithium-ion batteries Anode 1 Introduction The rapid global adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has created an unprecedented challenge for advanced lithium-ion battery technology [1]. Currently, the expectation for EVs charging times is approaching those of conventional refueling (<15 min), imperatively making breakthroughs in fast-charging battery systems [2–7]. The conventional graphite anodes offer relatively high specific capacity (372 mA h g−1) and excellent cycling reversibility. However, their sluggish Li+ diffusion kinetics and propensity for lithium dendrite formation, unfortunately, pose significant safety concerns, rendering it unsuitable for fast-charging applications [7–12]. As promising alternatives, niobium-based oxides and their derivatives have attracted considerable attention due to their dominant bulk pseudocapacitive behavior [13,14]. This unique charge storage mechanism enables simultaneous fast Faradaic reactions at both surface and bulk sites, circumventing solid-state diffusion limitations to enhance fast-charging capability [15–17]. Furthermore, the presence of multiple redox couples (Nb5+/Nb4+ and Nb4+/Nb3+) contributes to higher theoretical capacity [18]. Crucially, their operating potentials (>1.0 V vs. Li+/Li) significantly exceed those of graphite (0.1 V) and lithium metal (0 V), thermodynamically suppressing lithium plating risks and thereby improving safety markedly [19–21]. In recent years, niobium-based oxides (e.g., Nb2O5, FeNb11O29, CoNb2O6, TiNb2O7, PNb9O25, W3Nb14O44) have been widely studied as fast-charging anode materials due to their high theoretical capacity and multi-electron redox activity [22–29]. Among them, Wadsley-Roth phase FeNb11O29 is considered a promising candidate for next-generation anodes, owing to its abundant Fe3+/Fe2+, Nb5+/Nb4+, and Nb4+/Nb3+ redox sites and high theoretical capacity of 400 mA h g−1 [30]. However, the certain limitations hinder its practical application: the lower conductivity causes sluggish charge transfer kinetics at high rates, the method of synthesis is relatively traditional (mostly solid-phase synthesis) [31,32], and electrochemically inactive impurities form during synthesis, reducing active material utilization [33]. Various modification strategies have been proposed to address these issues. Zheng et al. synthesized FeNb11O29 nanotubes that delivered 100 mA h g−1 after 2000 cycles at 10 C [34]. Huang’s group achieved a 0.1 C capacity of 318 mA h g−1 via Al3+ doping [35]. Fu et al. developed porous carbon-coated FeNb11O29− X @C nanosheets with dual functionality for lithium storage and OER catalysis [36]. Nevertheless, these modified materials still struggle to meet fast charging demands at ultrahigh rates (>30 C), and complex modification methods increase production costs [32,37,38]. Thus, developing unmodified FeNb11O29 materials with inherent high-rate capability and structural stability without complex modifications, holds significant scientific value for advancing fast-charging battery technologies. Herein, we demonstrate a Fe-driven phase transformation of Nb2O5 to synthesize phase-pure Wadsley-Roth FeNb11O29 (FNO) nanoparticles. Structural analysis revealed the interconnected [FeO6] and [NbO6] octahedra of FNO form three-dimensional open channels for Li+ diffusion, which not only ensures structural stability during cycling but also facilitates rapid Li+ transport. Besides, FNO holds a narrowed bandgap, accounting for its superior electronic conductivity. Therefore, FNO has great potential in fast-charging anode material. Consequently, it achieves a full charge/discharge cycle in merely 25 s while retaining a high reversible capacity of ∼90 mA h g−1. Moreover, an exceptional cycling stability was demonstrated with over 2500 cycles in half cell. Thus, a superior rate capability was obtained in comparison with other reports of Nb-based oxide anode materials. The lithium storage mechanism associated with structural formation and evolution is systematically investigated through in situ structural characterization and electrochemical kinetic analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis The FNO nanoparticles were synthesized via a high-temperature calcination method using precursors obtained through a solvothermal synthesis. Specifically, 2 g of terephthalic acid (PTA) was dissolved in 80 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and stirred on a magnetic stirrer for 2 h. Subsequently, 4 mmol of niobium pentachloride (NbCl5) was added to the resulting solution, followed by the addition of varying ratios of iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) as the Fe source, and the mixture was stirred for another 2 h. The stirred solution was then transferred into a 100 mL autoclave and maintained at 200 ℃ in an oven for 12 h. After natural cooling, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed five times with ethanol, and dried at 60 ℃ for 24 h to obtain the precursor powder. The as-prepared precursor powder was thoroughly ground and transferred into a ceramic boat, followed by calcination in air at a heating rate of 5 ℃ min−1 up to 800 ℃ for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, the final powder sample was obtained. Through control of Fe/Nb feedstock ratios (0:1 to 0.75:1), four distinct samples were synthesized: (i) Pristine orthorhombic Nb2O5 (denoted as P-NO, Fe/Nb = 0:1); (ii) A biphasic composite of Nb2O5 and FeNb11O29 (P-NO@FNO, Fe/Nb = 0.25:1); (iii) Phase-pure FeNb11O29 (FNO, Fe/Nb = 0.5:1); (iv) FeNb11O29 with minor FeNbO4 (FNO@FeNbO4, Fe/Nb = 0.75:1). 2.2 Cell assembly Electrochemical tests used CR2032 coin cells (NEWARE). For half-cells, the working electrode contained 70 wt% active material, 20 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), homogenized (30 min grinding) and coated on Cu foil, then vacuum-dried at 60 ℃ overnight. Lithium foil (kelude) served as counter/reference electrode with GF/D separator (Whatman) and 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1:1 wt%) electrolyte. All assembly occurred in an Ar glovebox (O2/H2O < 0.1 ppm). For full-cell assembly, LiFePO4 (Shenzhen KeJing, TO2) was employed as the cathode active material, with the remaining assembly process identical to that of the anode. The anode-to-cathode capacity ratio was carefully controlled within 1.0–1.1. Prior to full-cell fabrication, the FNO anode underwent pre-lithiation treatment by cycling in a half-cell configuration at 0.1 C for 10 cycles, followed by disassembly in an argon-filled glovebox at a lithiation state of 1.0 V (vs. Li+/Li). The full-cell operation voltage window was set between 0.8 and 3.5 V to ensure stable electrochemical performance. 2.3 Material characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Riguaku SmartLab diffractometer with Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) over a 2θ range of 10°–80°, operating at 40 kV and 200 mA. Morphological analysis was performed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU-8010). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were conducted on a JEM-2100F microscope operating at 200 kV (no special treatment was required for the weakly magnetic sample), with high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) performed on a JEM ARM300F Grand ARM instrument. Elemental composition was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Thermo Scientific) via kinetic energy discrimination (KED) mode. Surface area measurements were obtained through nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Additional characterization included Raman spectroscopy (Princeton GRS TR777-2), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB QXi), time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS, TESCAN S9000G All in One), and UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (HITACHI U-4100). 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The NEWARE battery testing systems (CT-4008T-5 V 50 mA-164, Shenzhen, China) were used to perform constant-current charging and discharging within a voltage range of 1.0 to 3.0 V. Cyclic voltammetry (CV, 1.0–3.0 V at various scan rates) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, 10 kHz–0.01 Hz) measurements were performed using a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. Galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) measurements (20 mA g−1 current) determined FNO’s ion diffusion coefficient through 20 min discharge/120 min rest cycles until reaching 1.0 V. 2.5 Theoretical calculation method The first-principles calculations were performed using the plane-wave pseudopotential method based on density functional theory (DFT), as implemented in the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [39]. The exchange-correlation functional was treated within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [40]. The electron-ion interactions were described by the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [41]. For structural optimization, the conjugate gradient technique was employed to relax both the lattice parameters and all atomic positions until the convergence criterion of 0.02 eV Å−1 was satisfied. The electronic wave functions were expanded with a plane-wave kinetic energy cutoff of 520 eV, and Brillouin zone integration utilized a Monkhorst-Pack k mesh of 2π × 0.03 Å−1 [42]. Electronic correlation effects were improved using the GGA+U approach for the exchange-correlation potential [43], where the effective on-site Coulomb interaction parameter U eff = U − J was set to 1.5 eV for the Nb d-states and 5.3 eV for the Fe d-states, with U representing the on-site Hubbard repulsion and J the Hund’s exchange interaction [37,44]. The selection of U eff is consistent with literature reports to address the on-site Coulombic interactions in the localized d electrodes of Fe/Nb ions [45–47]. 3 Result and discussion Through a solvothermal synthesis with controlled Fe incorporation, amorphous precursors were successfully synthesized (Fig. S1). Subsequent calcination yielded four distinct samples, as confirmed by comprehensive characterization. SEM analysis (Fig. S2) revealed that all samples exhibited uniform nanoparticulate morphologies with block-like structures (∼200 nm). Initial phase identification by XRD (Fig. 1a ) revealed four distinct material composition: pristine orthorhombic P-NO, a composite phase of P-NO and FNO (P-NO@FNO), phase-pure FNO, and a composite phase of FNO with trace FeNbO4 (FNO@FeNbO4). Refined XRD (Fig. 1b & Table S1) quantitatively elucidated the phase composition, revealing a progressive Fe-driven phase transformation from P-NO to FNO. At optimal Fe/Nb ratios (0.5:1), a pure FNO phase was achieved, while excessive Fe led to the formation of FeNbO4 (16.21% in FNO@FeNbO4). ICP-MS analysis (Table S2) further validated the stoichiometry of FNO, with Fe/Nb ≈ 1:11.175, aligning perfectly with theoretical expectations. DFT calculations (Table S3) demonstrated that FNO exhibits a lower formation energy (−6.325 eV atom−1) compared to P-NO (−6.270 eV atom−1), confirming the thermodynamic preference for Fe-induced phase transformation. The energy difference (−0.055 eV atom−1) provides quantitative evidence for the Fe-driven structural evolution. Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S3) tracked the structural evolution, showing the disappearance of [NbO7] polyhedra in P-NO and the emergence of [FeO6] octahedra in FNO [48,49]. Furthermore, the weak peak at 820 cm−1 (attributed to elongated Nb–O bond) reflects the corner-sharing octahedral structure characteristic of FNO [38]. From the above spectroscopic analysis, it can be concluded that with the increase of Fe source during the preparation process, the sample is transformed from P-NO to FNO (Fig. 1c). The P-NO consists of distorted octahedra [NbO6] and pentagonal bipyramids [NbO7]. The introduction of Fe eliminates the original [NbO7] coordination in P-NO and leads to the formation of new [FeO6] octahedra. These [FeO6] octahedra, together with the [NbO6] octahedra, form a 3 × 4 block-like fundamental unit. These building blocks undergo staggered shearing along the [001] direction through corner-sharing and edge-sharing connections, while maintaining interlayer spacing along [010]. BET analysis (Fig. S4) confirmed that the phase transformation did not significantly alter the specific surface area or pore size distribution. Crystal structure characterization was performed using TEM, revealing that both P-NO and FNO consist of ∼200 nm block nanoparticles (Fig. S5). For P-NO, the measured lattice spacings corresponding to (20−1), (180), and (−181) crystal planes (Fig. 1d) showed excellent agreement with theoretical XRD values. In FNO (Fig. 1e), the orthogonal (800) and (006) planes (90.0° interplanar angle) correlate with the high-intensity diffraction peaks at 24.79° and 25.90° in the XRD pattern. Atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 1f) revealed the (011) (d = 3.76 Å) and (006) (d = 3.44 Å) lattice planes along the [100] zone axis in FNO, with an acute angle of 79.5°. The fast Fourier transform (FFT, Fig. 1f inset) pattern matched well with theoretical predictions. The atomic structure model of FNO showed excellent correspondence with HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 1g). Line scanning analysis of Z-contrast intensity of atomic column (Fig. 1h) revealed distinct variations in contrast along specific crystallographic directions, representing compositional differences among atomic columns. According to Z-contrast principles, the inverse correlation between Z-contrast signal intensity and oxygen atomic percentage [50]. This demonstrated that columns with higher oxygen percentage exhibited lower intensity, whereas those dominated by heavier Fe/Nb atoms showed stronger signal intensity. This observation shows excellent agreement with the theoretical crystal structure occupancy of Fe, Nb, and O atoms. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy elemental mapping (EDX, Fig. 1i) confirms the homogeneous distribution of Fe throughout the FNO matrix. To investigate the electrochemical performance of the FNO anode material, the Li||FNO half cell was assembled for electrochemical testing. As shown in Fig. 2a & Fig. S6, the CV curves reveal that compared to the P-NO material, additional Fe3+/Fe2+ redox peaks appear in the FNO electrode within 2.1–2.7 V, confirming the contribution of Fe to for Li storage. It is noteworthy that the CV curves of the subsequent cycles of FNO highly overlap with the first cycle, suggesting that it has excellent cyclic reversibility. Quantitative analysis (Fig. 2b) reveals that the integrated CV area of FNO is larger (27.1%) than that of P-NO. It can be attributed to the introduction of Fe, not only providing additional redox-active sites but also synergistically enhancing the Li-storage activity of Nb, thereby improving the charge storage capability of FNO [32,33,35]. This conclusion is further supported by galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) tests (Fig. 2c), where FNO exhibits characteristic charge/discharge plateaus at 2.1–2.7 V, well-aligned with the Fe redox peaks observed in CV. As a result, FNO delivers a first-cycle charge capacity of 265.4 mA h g−1 with a high Coulombic efficiency of 92.1%, significantly outperforming P-NO (170.5 mA h g−1 and 84.3%, respectively). We also explored the fast-charging ability of FNO. As shown in Fig. S7 & Fig. 2d, one can see that FNO delivers a high discharge capacity of 280.5 mA h g−1 at 0.25 C. When the current density is progressively increased to 75 C (equivalent to completing charge/discharge in 25 s), FNO still maintains a reversible capacity of ∼90 mA h g−1. In contrast, P-NO exhibits only <20 mA h g−1 at 75 C, and its capacity at 0.25 C remains 110 mA h g−1 lower than that of FNO. Remarkably, this rate performance surpasses most reported FNO systems and other niobium-based oxides (Fig. 2e & Table S4), representing a breakthrough in fast-charging niobium-based materials [32,34,35,37,51,52]. Subsequently, long-term cycling tests were conducted on P-NO and FNO to evaluate their cycling stability. As shown in Fig. S8, FNO demonstrates exceptional capacity retention of 91.2% after 500 cycles at 12.5 C. Even under ultrahigh-rate cycling at 75 C for 2500 cycles (Fig. 2f), it maintains a reversible capacity of 85.8 mA h g−1, corresponding to a 92.8% retention rate. In contrast, the capacity of P-NO decays to less than 40 mA h g−1 after cycling. These results clearly indicate that FNO exhibits significantly superior cycling stability compared to P-NO and other composite samples (Fig. S9). To elucidate the electrochemical kinetics differences between FNO and P-NO electrodes, a series of systematic electrochemical investigations was conducted. CV measurements were performed at varying scan rates (Fig. 3a & Fig. S10), followed by quantitative analysis of the current ( i ) and scan rate ( v ) relationship using the following equation [53] (1) i = a v b # where i represents the peak current, v denotes the scan rate, and a and b are adjustable parameters. The b -values were determined from the slope of log ( i ) versus log ( v ) plots, serving as quantitative indicators of charge storage mechanisms. Typically, the b -value of 0.5 signifies diffusion-controlled processes, while b = 1.0 corresponds to capacitive-dominated behavior. In particular, the calculated b -values for the redox peaks of both P-NO and FNO (Fig. 3b) fall around 0.9 (with additional b -values for secondary peak pairs of FNO provided in Fig. S11 & Table S5), pseudocapacitive-like kinetics despite the bulk redox reactions, suggesting rapid surface-controlled charge storage. Importantly, FNO has a higher b -value, indicating that it has faster reaction kinetics. The contribution ratio of the cell and capacitance can be calculated by the formula [54] (2) i = k 1 v + k 2 v 1 2 # where i indicates the current value at a specific voltage, k 1 v is capacitive current, k 2 v 1 2 is diffusion current, and v is scan rate. According to the above formula, it is found that the capacitance control of FNO electrode is higher than that of traditional P-NO (Fig. 3c), and the capacitance contribution can reach 96.3% at the scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1, further indicating its faster kinetics (Fig. S12). As shown in Fig. 3d, EIS at room temperature revealed a significantly lower charge transfer resistance (R ct) for FNO (26.86 Ω) compared to P-NO (43.79 Ω), highlighting its superior ionic transport properties. This observation aligns with the general trend that smaller particle sizes typically exhibit lower R ct values, as evidenced by comparative data in Table S6. To further investigate the temperature dependence of charge transfer kinetics, EIS measurements were conducted from 25 to 60 ℃ (Fig. S13). With increasing temperature, the R ct of FNO decreased from 26.86 Ω (25 ℃) to 3.26 Ω (60 ℃), while P-NO exhibited a more pronounced reduction (43.79 to 2.5 Ω), indicating that FNO possesses lower thermal sensitivity. The Arrhenius relationship between R ct and temperature (T) was analyzed by plotting log (R ct) against 1000/T (Fig. 3e & Table S7). The calculated activation energy for FNO (2.50 eV) was notably lower than that of P-NO (3.48 eV), demonstrating faster surface charge transfer kinetics in FNO that directly contributes to its enhanced rate performance. In addition, GITT tests show (Fig. 3f) that the lithium-ion diffusion coefficient of FNO electrode is greater than that of P-NO electrode, further confirming its favorable kinetics. In the preceding electrochemical tests, FNO demonstrated superior lithium-ion diffusion capability, lower charge transfer resistance, and higher capacity retention compared to P-NO, particularly at high current densities. This performance disparity primarily originates from their distinct electronic structures. To gain deeper insight into the underlying mechanism, we performed DFT calculations to determine the band gaps of P-NO and FNO. As illustrated in Fig. 3g, h, the band gap of FNO (1.23 eV) is significantly lower than that of P-NO (2.05 eV). The smaller band gap makes it easier for electrons to transition from valence band to conduction band, indicating that its intrinsic conductivity will increase and it will have lower charge transfer resistance [55–57]. The high electron conductivity of FNO synergistically promotes Li+ diffusion and improves capacity retention at high current densities [58,59]. This theoretical prediction was experimentally verified by UV-Vis DRS, where the measured band gaps showed excellent agreement with theoretical calculation trend (Fig. 3i). Further evidence comes from ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy confirms (UPS, Fig. 3j) that the decrease in the work function (2.26 eV) of FNO indicates an upward shift in the Fermi level. This fabulous electronic structure optimizes the extraction/insertion reaction kinetics by strengthening Li+ adsorption energy, ultimately contributing to the material’s exceptional reversible capacity. All of the above analyses collectively demonstrate that FNO exhibits pseudocapacitance-dominated charge storage behavior, enabling ultrafast electrochemical dynamics. Such enhanced kinetics can be attributed to the synergistic effects of the unique Wadsley-Roth phase structure, which facilitates rapid Li+ diffusion, and its Fe-modulated narrow bandgap, which improves electronic conductivity. These intrinsic advantages not only promote efficient ion/electron transport but also underpin the outstanding rate capability of FNO, making it a promising high-power anode material. The exceptional electrochemical performance is intrinsically linked to the microstructural evolution of material during cycling. A combination of in situ and ex situ characterization techniques was employed to investigate the structural transformation and Li+ insertion/extraction mechanisms (Fig. 4 ). In situ XRD analysis (Fig. 4a) reveals continuous peak shifts of all major diffraction peaks during cycling without emergence of new phases, demonstrating a predominant solid-solution reaction mechanism. The smaller peak shift magnitude during the initial cycle relative to subsequent cycles suggests a characteristic first-cycle activation process, consistent with reported Wadsley-Roth phase niobium oxides. And this behavior likely stems from partial lithium retention in the host structure during initial activation [51]. Importantly, the material maintained well-defined peak profiles and fully reversible peak positions throughout all cycles, confirming its intrinsic structural stability. HRTEM analysis (Fig. 4b, c) further demonstrates anisotropic lattice strain evolution, with the (011) interplanar spacing expanding from 3.76 Å to 3.83 Å while the (800) plane contracts from 3.59 to 3.51 Å, findings that correlate well with XRD results (Fig. S14). Importantly, the FNO forms a thin and uniform solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer even under full lithiation (Fig. S15), attributed to its high working potential (>1.0 V vs. Li+/Li) that effectively suppresses electrolyte decomposition and enhances cycling safety. To elucidate the capacity fading mechanisms at ultrahigh rate (75 C), TOF-SIMS was performed on both pristine (Fig. S16) and discharged electrodes of FNO (Fig. 4d, e). The images reveal a gradient distribution of lithium signals, with top-view image showing relatively uniform Li+ incorporation across the FNO surface. Cross-sectional analysis indicates that the high current density restricts Li+ diffusion to a shallow depth [60]. The resulting partial lithiation has been determined to be the dominant factor responsible for the capacity degradation observed at ultrahigh rates. Ex situ XPS analysis (Fig. 4f, g) provides compelling evidence for the multi-electron redox reactions of Nb and reversible Fe valence changes. The Nb 3d spectra exhibit significant peak shifts corresponding to the valence transitions between Nb5+, Nb4+, and Nb3+. Similarly, the Fe 2p 3/2 orbital shows a 1.41 eV shift (711.09–709.68 eV) [61]. Both elements fully recover their initial oxidation states after complete charging, demonstrating exceptional electrochemical reversibility [62]. Morphological evolution analysis via SEM characterization (Fig. S17) of electrodes at different cycling stages demonstrates exceptional structural integrity, where FNO maintains pristine particle morphology without observable cracks or volumetric expansion even after 2500 ultrahigh-rate cycles at 75 C, confirming outstanding safety characteristics. This remarkable structural stability originates from the unique Wadsley-Roth crystalline framework, wherein the synergistic cooperation between [NbO6] and [FeO6] octahedra simultaneously establishes three-dimensional lithium-ion diffusion pathways and effectively accommodates cyclic lattice strain [27,63]. These findings explain the structural basis for FNO’s combination of ultrahigh-rate performance and ultra-long cycle life. Based on the exceptional electrochemical performance in half cell, we fabricated full cells containing FNO anodes paired with LiFePO4 (LFP) cathodes to evaluate their practical feasibility. The FNO||LFP full cell (Fig. 5a ) delivers an average operating voltage of 1.85 V (Fig. 5b). As shown in Fig. 5c, the full cell exhibits initial charge/discharge capacities of 134/128 mA h g−1 at 5 C, achieving an impressive first-cycle Coulombic efficiency of 95.3%, and delivering stable for over 1000 cycles. The nearly superimposed GCD profiles (Fig. 5d) indicate minimal polarization, attributable to the robust electrode architecture and rapid reaction kinetics. In addition, the full cell demonstrates outstanding rate capability across a broad current density range (0.5–30 C), delivering specific capacities of 151, 147, 141, 126, 106, 93, 83, and 65 mA h g−1, respectively (Fig. 5e). It is particularly noteworthy that under the ultra-high rate of 15 and 30 C (Fig. S18 & Fig. 5g), the full cell has achieved an ultra-long cycle life of 3500 times (capacity retention 91.2%) and 10000 times (capacity retention 90.8%) respectively. Surprisingly, the single charge and discharge time is shorter than 2 min (at 30 C). This performance breaks through the fast-charging technological limitations of currently reported FNO systems (Table S8). Ragone plot analysis (Fig. 5f) further confirms the advantages of this system [29,37,64–66]: FNO electrode can exhibit a high energy density of 322.2 Wh kg−1 at the power density of 177.7 W kg−1, while maintaining an energy output of 113.3 Wh kg−1 at an ultra-high power density of 6910.0 W kg−1. This achievement is also significantly better than the reported fast-charging anode materials such as FNO, Li4Ti5O12 and Nb2O5, which establishes FNO’s leading position in the next generation of fast-charging batteries. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, nano-sized Wadsley-Roth FNO were synthesized via Fe-driven phase transformation of Nb2O5. A three-dimensional open structure can provide a smooth Li+ diffusion channel, and the narrow band gap shows excellent conductivity, thus ensuring high-rate performance at the micro-scale. Based on the initial orthorhombic niobium pentoxide, the introduction of Fe can not only provide additional energy storage but also promote the redox activity of Nb. Thereby, the FNO anode can achieve ultra-fast charge (one cycle in 25 s) and long-term cycle stability (75 C, 2500 cycles, capacity retention rate up to 92.8%). Even more impressive is that the full battery provides an ultra-high-power density of 6910.0 W kg−1 at 30 C (no more than 2 min per cycle), can maintain more than 10000 cycles, and exhibits a long-term cycle capacity retention rate of 90.8%. Considering FNO’s excellent fast charging performance, excellent conductivity, and high stability, our prepared FNO is expected to be an ultra-high rate and high safety anode material for LIBs. coredata.dc:description: Niobium-based oxides show great potential in anode materials for fast-charging lithium-ion batteries, but their practical application remains hindered by intrinsically low conductivity. In this study, we successfully synthesize nano-sized Wadsley-Roth FeNb11O29 through Fe-driven phase transformation of Nb2O5, which delivers a high specific capacity (280.5 mA h g−1 at 0.25 C) along with abundant redox-active sites. Moreover, the Wadsley-Roth shear structure of FeNb11O29 facilitates rapid Li+ diffusion and guarantees exceptional structural stability. Theoretical calculations further confirm that FeNb11O29 has a narrow bandgap, which significantly enhances the conductivity. Owing to these merits, FeNb11O29 achieves a full charge/discharge cycle within merely 25 s at 75 C rate and retains remarkable cycling stability over 2500 cycles. As a consequence, our assembled FeNb11O29||LiFePO4 full cell demonstrates ultra-long cyclability (>10000 cycles) and outstanding fast-charging capability (complete cycling within 2 min at 30 C). These findings highlight nano-sized FeNb11O29 as a highly promising anode candidate for next-generation fast-charging LIBs.
